When government and commerce were both on the side of exploiting a class of human being (as it is today in America with Mexican slaves), the odds seemed insurmountable unless you had a great faith in the Almighty who controls the destiny of all history (may He raise up new warriors to free the illegal Mexican slaves in America from both the pseudo-liberals and the greedy capitalists who are invested in the status quo). reviewText: Actually, let's give Michael Apted's "Amazing Grace" 4.5 stars and let's look at the strengths of the film first.First, when you start with a plot about the abolition of slavery in the British Empire, and intertwine, accurately, historic characters such as Fox, Pitt the Younger, Tarelton, and the Duke of Clarence, you are starting with a strong story.  Focus on the main character--MP William Wilberforce and his indefatigable efforts, and you have a winner.Next, work with the copious records and documents to stay historically faithful.  Throw in Wilberforce's strong relationship with John Newton, a former slave ship captain turned cleric, and author of the title hymn.  How can you miss?This film's greatest virtue besides the great historic tale is the fine acting. Ioan Gruffudd as Wilberforce is supplemented by many of the finest talents of British Cinema including Albert Finney as Newton, Rufus Sewell, Nicholas Farrell, and Toby Jones. The script crackles, allowing them all to display their talents.If the film has a technical weak point, it is it's odd use of flashbacks, flash forwards and strange "two years later" time increments.  It's a little hard to follow, but not unwatchable at all.If there is a historic weak point of the film, it has to be "Where's Wesley?"  John Wesley, founder of the Methodist Church was mainly remembered when he died in 1803 as a premier fighter against slavery in the UK.  Living contemporaneously with Wilberforce, not even giving him a mention seems a major historic omission.But, otherwise, great, inspirational entertainment.  Good cinematography and soundtrack round out a top film worthy of repeated watchings.

reviewText: Wonderful story about 1800s England and fight for abolition of slavery.  We see perception of slavery and slave trade from the upper class England nobles point of view.  Young man, Wilberforce, sensitive and caring by nature is compelled to make it his life mission to fight peacefully for the abolition of slavery in colonial England.  At the time when England is the most powerful country in the world and has many colonies, when interests of the rich and powerful are so carefully protected and Jacobian revolution in France is gaining is revolutionary force, young Wilberforce is threading carefully in his efforts to preserve human diginity for African slaves without looking like a revolutionary seeking to overthrow royal traditions of England.  It is powerful movie, full of wisdom and quiet sensitivity.  It is also amazing to learn how power has no mercy towards individuals who are carrying it out.  With increased responsibilites and genuine concern, come illness and weakening of the body.  We see England's Prime Minister William Pitt, age and die prematurely once burdens of the political life take over his physical strength.  This is important film about important moment in England's history that affected the rest of the world in the most profound way, without any use of force or military power.  "Amazing Grace" as amazing movie.

reviewText: I was familiar with the story of William Wilberforce from what I read of him in Peter Marshall's From Sea to Shining Sea, and remember thinking at the time that Mr. Wilberforce should be better known for the incredible work he did to abolish the slave trade in England. It was a story of courage and sacrifice, and it seemed strange that I had never heard it before. The character of William also fascinated me. So when I saw this yesterday I literally pounced on it, knowing it had to be great. It was great, though it focused more on what Williams faith produced than on his faith itself. Beautifully filmed and thouhtfully written, the little known story of a compassionate and strong-willed young man who changed history was brought to life with an all British cast. The settings and costumes were good, and the acters were well chosen. The array of eccentric characters made it seem a bit like Dickens. Wilberforce himself was an odd man, with poor people he didn't know crowding his dining room at lunch time and all kinds of animals running around. His friend Thomas Clarkston caught my eye every time he came on screen. He didn't have many lines and never changed his expression, but Rufus Sewell can do more with a wistful, stoney glare than most actors can do with a dozen speeches. An intrigueing, dark character, greying, sandy hair swaying in the breeze beneath a scare-crow hat . . . And Pitt, another friend of Wilberforce, is convincing in a quiet way. Would watch it again just to hear his accent. The special features are as rich as the movie. Actor interviws, a music video by Chris Tomlin, and a section where a young modern-day abolitionist speaks out on slavery today. Politics often stand in the way of justice, now, as then, and this movie reminds us not to quit fighting for what's right when the tide of political sway is against you. "If not you, who? If not now, when?"

reviewText: On the surface it is a historical movie about the work of William Wilberforce against the English participation in the African slave trade at the turn of the 19th century.But i think that the writer's had much more to say about English society than this, things that are still important and ought to be considered.Their deeper criticism is about the hierarchical nature of English society, the rulers and the ruled, the elite landowning and servant owning class and the masses of people toiling in the farms, fields and factories. There are several places where this criticism breaks the surface of the movie: the scene where the servant steps over the fence and sits in the field with Wilberforce and together contemplate spider webs, the scene in Parliament where the Whig opposition leader asks Wilberforce "the people?", and the analogy of America opening the bottle of revolution and France pouring it out.The defenders of America slavery in the 19thC took the issue of the hierarchical nature of society very much to heart, Robert Dabney in defense of virginia, stated boldly that without a natural hierarchy and an elite of rulers, and an underclass of slaves, Christian society was doomed to a radical equalitarianism stemming from the French revolution's atheistic call of arms.Wilberforce himself was an independent, but he supported wholeheartedly the Tory administration of his friend William Pitt, elements of this friendship make up a substantial thread in Amazing Grace. It is the Tory flurtation with French revolutionary thought that gets Wilberforce and others in trouble during the war years with France. The movie firmly takes a stand not only against the slave trade, for the moral improvement program of Wilberforce, but for the gradual flattening of English society into a meritocratic democracy rather than the traditional Whiggish view of elitism, as the movie so aptly sums it up near the end in the term-"Nobilis oblige".What i find curious is that only one review here hints at the larger criticism of society that this movie attempts. Slavery is not a burning issue in our society, but wage-slavery (as the wobblies pointed out) is much the same thing, elitism and a heritary hierarchy without reference to individual achievement is a big problem in England and an increasing problem in Western culture in general and the US in particular. If you look at the movie in this way it becomes not so much a criticism of a form of economics which rightly died in the mid 19thC, but part of an ongoing struggle for genuine participation in political and social life for all people, not only the ruling classes.I think that the writers avoided strongly pursuing this theme because the current climate of the natural audience of the movie, Christians are far more aligned with Whiggish theories of history and economics then classical liberal Tory type views and they really couldnt sell the movie to this group if they had made the elements stronger. but the fact that in Christ there is no Jew nor Gentile, no rich or poor, the theme of the field scene about spider webs and such, is one of the greatest criticisms of a hierarchical society that mankind has ever believed.It is a good movie, just look a bit deeper than a historical piece about Wilberforce and the ending of the british slave trade. it is an amazing and productive period of history and i'm glad someone was able to make a somewhat popular movie about a few of the pieces of the puzzle that is the Whig-Tory 18-19thC dance.
summary: more than a simple historical movie

reviewText: "Amazing Grace" is not the story about the classic hymn as the ads and title lead you to believe, it instead attempts to tell the story of English abolitionist William Wilberforce. Wilberforce's struggle to dismantle the horrific slave trade in Britain is a story worthy of a film, but unfortunately "Amazing Grace" plays more like a crawling, unfocused costume drama that comes across more as a bad TV movie than a serious motion picture. It also unsuccessfully juggles multiple story arcs, creating a fractured narrative that makes the film lose any real power or punch. There are good scenes in this movie, and some decent production values, but it never fully engages the viewer. The film also makes the mistake of forgetting a crucial element of the story: The slaves.The movie begins with a fascinating scene where Wilberforce shows his compassion for all of God's creatures by stopping a man on a side of the road who whips a black horse, the narrative then jumps to some of Wilberforce's colleagues trying to make a love connection between Wilberforce and a pretty English girl who has followed his abolotinist work for years. It is here where the jumping back and fourth begins as the film decides not to keep a focused narrative and instead employ a flashback technique where the resolutions of certain story arcs are revealed before they even begin. We meet some interesting characters, including a former slave ship captain who wrote the hymn "Amazing Grace" and is haunted by the memories of his former trade. He gets the best dialogue in the movie, and you wonder, indeed, why the movie isn't about him.Director Michael Apted, best known for the 007 film "The World Is Not Enough," surprisingly exchanges power and impact for cheesy romance and cornball scenes between friends. Like the films "Luther" and "Alexander," Apted here shows a lot but tells too little. There are some good, intense scenes where the British MPs debate the issue of slavery and the economic importance it held at the time, but the very issue of slavery itself feels pushed back in a film which decides to be timid and safe about the subject. Wilberforce tours a slave ship, and we see a few chains on the roof, but we never meet the slaves, we never actually see their plight as in Steven Spielberg's "Amistad." There is only one major black character in the film, and he's only given a few lines in two scenes and then we simply discover he died after publishing his memoirs. After that, the African slaves Wilmberforce is fighting for have no identity, they are, as with the former captain, ghosts.The character of Wilmberforce is also never treated like a flesh and blood person, a brilliant man pushing against the status quo. Oh there are classic moments of fist clenching and shouting, but Wilmberforce is reduced to a cardboard character, a cartoon who only says what we expect him to say. Even his faith, a major theme in a film obviously meant to cater to Christian audiences (Chris Tomlin even sings the title song), is never explored or even convincingly portrayed. How Wilmberforce really find God? We never know, it's all summed up in one corny scene where he sits in a field looking at the sky and observes the beauty of a spider-web, after that the rest of the movie reduced the importance of Wilmberforce's faith to just a few, typical lines like "we are all equal in the eyes of God." Can't disagree with the notion, but we're never convinced of the passion or fever of this man's beliefs. Instead of exploring where Wilmberforce's faith comes from, the script feels as if it just had to randomly throw in the word "God" in every few lines just to remind viewers this is a religious-friendly movie. But those seriously interested in Christian ideas in the fight against slavery will find nothing deep or profound. Valuable space is given to a very unconvincing love story between Wilmberforce and the woman he eventually marries. Their dialogue is suitable for a bad soap opera and we never feel as if these are actually two connected people bound together by anything. Even the films villains have little to no identity, they are simply qeued for every Parliament scene and then disappear in the background.We shouldn't expect movies to be historical guides, those who really want to inform themselves should go to the local public library instead, but the best historical films also take history seriously and with at least some detail. "Amazing Grace" simply skips around themes and events without showing their impact or importance. The American Revolution is mentioned and glorified (of course), but it never goes beyond that. Did Wilmberforce have any opinions on America's own slave culture? The Haitian Revolution is at least mentioned in one quick line, but you never know what Wilmberforce thought about it. Thomas Jefferson himself was terrified of the Haitian Revolution because it symbolized the ability of the slaves to rebel and even take power, Jefferson is only mentioned in passing in the film as suspected of corresponding with Wilmberforce eventhough they had completely different ideas of freedom for the slaves. The ending of the film is also a little tricky, I understand Apted has to give the audience what they want, a heroic, triumphant ending for the hero, but the way slavery is abolished is explained in a rapid, muddled narrative. Of course the screenwriters had to find a way around the fact that Britain abolished slavery more for the purpose of hitting the French and American economies hard, not because Wilmberforce convinced the government of his moral battle.In the end "Amazing Grace" is a bad exercise in anglophile cinema, this is the kind of movie directors like Spike Lee and actors like Danny Globver must feel frustrated about. Glover himself has been trying to launch a film on the Haitian Revolution for years, but whenever he pitches the script around Hollywood, the answer according to him, is always the same: "Where are the white characters?" That is not to say "Amazing Grace" is some sort of racist film, it has too much of a good heart for that, but in trying to reduce Wilmberforce's struggle to a soapy message movie, the film loses sight of its subject and even its spiritual content. Even the title is not done justice, because the real story of "Amazing Grace" is surely a film worth making. This one has costumes, but no soul.

reviewText: I would place this film amongst the most powerful I have ever seen in a long life of cinema going.The script was brilliantly tight and barely a word was wasted. The sets were very authentic and cost I heard a reported 30 million. Beyond the walls of Wilberforce's home the world of London was presented in a dark and brooding manner which reinforced the sense of the legitimised evil that Wilberforce and his associates were fighting.The mainly ensemble British acting was of the highest order. Outstanding performances amongst others were given by Ioan Gruffudd who superbly conveyed the complexities of Wilberforce's character, Michael Gambon,Rufus Sewell,Benjamin Cumberbatch, and Romola Garai with a superb cameo of the reformed and redeemed slaver, John Newton, by Albert Finney.Balance was given by recognition of the important role of Oloudaqh Equiano played by Youssou N'Dorr.However, some historical license was taken in order to create dramatic effect.This included the Duke of Clarence sitting in the House of Commons and James Fox,one of the greatest orators and reformers of the day, giving the final paean of praise to Wilberforce when in history he had already died.Never mix politics and religion we are told, yet the film does it successfully by embellishing the issue with a real wit and humour.The power of the film lies to a great extent in its understatement which makes it very British and it will be interesting to see how well it does in the States.The deliberately diverted visit of MP's and their consorts to the moored slave ship was a metaphor of this. The power of the misery was conveyed without it being completely thrust in the face. The final tribute to Wilberforce was another notable example of the power of the use of a few chosen words rather than many.The film was both moving and inspirational. In this era of the quick fix, it reminded us, as do the lives of Nelson Mandela and Desmond Tutu,of the importance of never giving up in the fight for a more just and humane world. Evil prospers when good men and women do nothing -but we need to do it again and again and again. There are more slaves in the world today than there were at the time of abolition and I trust this film will inspire another generation to continue the struggle.For those who want a more politically correct revisionist view of history and who cry paternalism, it needs to be emphasised that Wilberforce and his supporters took on the might of the political and economic establishment of the day and won. Yes he was a compassionate man but he was also a great champion of justice and justice above all requires that we see those who we are trying to help as equals.This is an outstanding piece of film making that does justice to the achievement of Wilberforce and his associates

reviewText: This is a fine film with a good cast.  Anything with Ioin Gruffudd is usually good.  He was great in the Hornblower series.  This film deals with the issue of abolition, and how it started in England long before it was ever known in the States.  Fortunately this film does not become too preachy on a topic which is normally quite moralistic in tone.  The perspective here is more on the inner-workings of politics and how Wilberforce had to work the English parliamentry system to achieve his goal.  One must give the English system credit for passing such a measure without bloodshed, something which required a bloody Civil War in this country some 60 years later!The main interest for me in this film however is the massed band sequence at the end just before the credits.  The sight and sound of the bands is quite fascinating, even if not historically accurate. The tune "Amazing Grace" has long been associated with the Scottish pipes, although it is doubtful that it was played in the fashion shown here.  For one, pipers in the Scottish regiments were generally not known to play together until sometime later in the 19th century where they eventually combined with the drums to produce the sight and sound we know so well today.The military bands shown also would not likely have combined to play in this manner at that time.  The modern assocation we have today with the bands and pipes combination must come from the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards who made their version of "Amazing Grace" so famous in 1972.  The legend of that recording which those two bands of the regiment produced lives on today and even gets picked up in movies like this!  Still, the sight and sound of these bands in period unifroms, and with period instrumentation is fascinating for the true student of military music like myself.British military bands of the period rarely combined in larger ensembles than their own band, and on the rare occasions they did the results were often not promising.  We are reminded of the famous incident from the Crimean War where all the regimental bands tried playing "God Save The Queen" and did so in different keys and arrangements!  The resulting noise drove the Duke of Cambridge to create the Royal Military School of Music at Kneller Hall in 1857.  This venerable institution is now celebrating its 150th anniversary where it continues to turn out polished musicians for the remainig few British military bands of today.  Those wanting to catch a glimpse of the original "Amazing Grace" as made famous in 1972 should catch the 2008 USA Tour of the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards and the Band of the Coldstream Guards.

reviewText: William Wilberforce was a member of Parliament who earned his place in history by becoming one of the great English abolitionists of the late 1700s.  Inspired by his deep-abiding love for God and his commitment to Christian principles, he was instrumental in bringing an end to slavery in his nation.Written by Steven Knight and directed by Michael Apted, "Amazing Grace" plays like one of those historical costume dramas of yore - serious in tone, stolid in execution, inspirational in theme and handsome in appearance.  The movie provides an interesting history lesson, even if it doesn't always make for the most gripping or compelling of dramas - especially since its characters, Wilberforce included, often emerge as more two-dimensional than three-dimensional in nature.  Still, it's a great movie to look at, and the stodginess itself becomes almost reassuring in its old-fashioned comfiness.Ioan Gruffudd as Wilberforce and Albert Finney as John Newton, Wilberforce's spiritual mentor and the composer of the hymn "Amazing Grace," head a fine cast that includes Romola Garai, Benedict Cumberbatch, Rufus Sewell and Toby Jones as wellAnd when that final vote is taken to make slavery a thing of the past in England, well, prepare yourself for goose bumps and throat lumps aplenty.

reviewText: The true story about an unlikely hero with a non-heroic name, William Wilberforce.  The title of the movie comes from his association with and inspiration from the author of the greatest hymn and greatest work of Christian music ever written, "Amazing Grace".  The unlikely songwriter was reformed and repentant Christian ex-slave trader, John Newton, who, like Wilberforce, was a prime example of the liberal abolitionist Christians of the 18th and 19th centuries.  These great men provide a stark contrast between the conservative pseudo-Christians of today, who march in near total lockstep with the conservative business and political agenda, with the real Christian progressives (i.e., liberals) of yesteryear and today.  As accurately portrayed in the movie, the Christian liberal abolitionists squared-off in a David vs. Goliath mismatch against the united conservative business and political juggernaut of their time, in this case united behind the fortunes being made in the slave trade.  Instead of a civil war ending slavery, the British experienced the ending of this abomination due almost 100% to the determined efforts of the Christian abolitionists portrayed in the movie.The movie does a great job of capturing and portraying the dogged determination, principled perseverance, and ultimate victory of as unlikely a group of successful and inspirational protagonists as could be imagined.  Also shown are their moments of defeat and despair that make their story the substance of real life, as well as the monumental forces resistant to changing the financially rewarding status quo they faced.
summary: A Great Movie About an Even Greater Story

reviewText: This is the story of one man on a mission to end the English slave trade.William Wilberforce (Ioan Gruffudd) was an English member of parliament in the late 18th and early 19th century.  He had a Christian experience and was led to eliminate the abomination of slavery.  Although he was a person of extraordinary wealth and privilege, Wilberforce was driven to do the right thing.This movie is a testament to the power that a single person who is focused can have.  In addtion to the protagonist, there are outstanding performances by John Newton (Albert Finney), Barbara Spooner (Romola Garai) and William Pitt (Benedict Cumberpatch).It took far too long for me to get around to seeing this one.  It is one that I would not mind seeing again and I can heartily endorse it for anyone who loves an inspirational story.  It is also a good history lesson and just plain great entertainment.

reviewText: 'Amazing Grace' is the story of William Wilberforce and his fight to abolish slavery in Britain. The first part of the film is told via flashback and then after shows how he finally managed to pass his abolition act. Ioan Gruffudd acts the role of Wilberforce supremely and very soon into the film you are completely gripped and are following the story intently. The excellent costumes and scenery really add to the overall feel of the film and help immerse you in the period. The politics of the time are explored reasonably well and the details of the act and Wilberforce's struggle are recounted in enough depth, but without becoming too dry. At just under two hours, this film manages to keep you interested for the whole duration and yet makes you feel you have a good understanding of the issues. This is well worth a viewing, it's not your fast paced action film (nor does it try to be), but a slow, steady builder and all the better for it.Feel free to check out my blog which can be found on my profile page.

reviewText: "Amazing Grace" is an exceptional film that chronicles the amazing true story of William Wilberforce, the man who spent twenty years in the British Parliament fighting to end one of mankind's greatest injustices: the slave trade. The film features powerful performances by an outstanding cast, including Ioan Gruffudd ("Fantastic Four," "King Arthur," TV's "Horatio Hornblower") as Wilberforce, whose faith and courage drove his fight for social justice. Albert Finney gives an amazing performance as John Newton, the former slave-ship captain turned pastor, and writer of the beloved hymn "Amazing Grace." Michael Gambon, Romola Garai, Youssou N'Dour, Rufus Sewell, and Nicholas Farrell give outstanding supporting performances.The rest of the crew does a fantastic job of bringing the world of 18th/19th Century Britain to life. "Amazing Grace" is an amazing film that shows how men of faith can truly help change the world. Amazing Grace, indeed!Grade: A

reviewText: In this inspiring story of William Wilberforce and the movement to abolish slavery, we are once again challenged that one man motivated toward good can accomplish much.  Standing for justice in an unjust world is swimming against the tide of current cultural norms at times but the end is sure as long as one stands.  As with so many, there were unfortunate liberties taken with historical fact with this film but the overall affect was true, at least in spirit.  Mr. Wilberforce's faith rings authentic in the film and the results on his life and political views were unmistakable.  The message is loud and clear, good does indeed triumph - at times it seems slow in coming but the end is inevitable when we are firm.The cultural norms of the Mr. Wilberforce's day seem foreign and unthinkable to us today.  One wonders what norms of today will be obvious moral and civil rights issues tomorrow.  Will history record that we were on the right side of those issues or will it find us with a majority that resists what is right?  Each must examine their own conscience.  May we, like Wilberforce, find the courage to be on the side of political right rather than political expediency.  That, I think, is the theme of this important film.
summary: With God, One is a Majority

reviewText: As the title for this review suggests, I absolutely loved this film. In fact, I really can't find much to criticize in it. It is highly accurate historically (with a few very minor exceptions - for example, I'm told that they were a little off in how long John Newton was a slave trader), has a very engaging and inspiring true-life story about a great Christian statesman, and was very well done artistically. This isn't your low-budget B movie that many associate with the Christian film genre; unlike films like "Left Behind," the production values of this film are great (in fact, it was produced by one of the major Hollywood studios and has production values comparable to other major Hollywood films). To make a long story short, it has everything you could want from a truly great, possibly even classic, movie. The acting was great, the sets were great, the writing was great, the cinematography was great, and the editing and all the other technical aspects were right on target too.My only minor complaint was I'm not sure I agree with how they portrayed John Newton. They portray him as being plagued by guilt about his past. I'm not sure if that was a historical reality that they had to portray or a decision they made about how to portray it.With that said, I thought this was a wonderful movie. If you didn't catch it in theaters, you'll definitely want to see it on DVD.

reviewText: Ioan Gruffudd gives an invigorating performance as William Wilberforce, the sharp-witted, determined supporter of abolition in Amazing Grace, the true story of one man's struggle against a kingdom. With impressive performances from an equally impressive cast, this epic battle is one fought not with blood and steel, but of intelligent words and cunning linguistics. Brimming with intricate character development, pertinent morals, and thematic gusto, Amazing Grace is a period piece not confined by its period or the piece of history it so masterfully depicts.In 18th century England, William Wilberforce (Ioan Gruffudd) fought tirelessly in Parliament to end slavery and the slave trade throughout the British Empire. Amazing Grace chronicles his successes and defeats and also delves deeper into the life of the remarkable idealist and the events that shaped and influenced his extraordinary career. Forced to contend with debilitating illness as well as the ruthlessly powerful and deviously manipulative lords supporting the slave trade, Wilberforce overcame adverse odds and managed to construct a diverse and unexpectedly strong movement for abolition. Comprised of a flashback structure that relates his many tribulations, Amazing Grace also reveals a poignant tale of love, friendship, and the unending efforts that led to his monumental achievements.Based on the true story of William Wilberforce and his endeavors in Parliament to abolish slavery, Amazing Grace utilizes flashbacks to connect the arcing storyline that traverses several years nonsequentially. At once both an engaging courtroom drama and a whimsical love story, the carefully structured film remains assertively paced throughout and the mood is seldom as grim as its subject matter would expectedly afford. Combined with compelling characters and subsequently affecting character development, Amazing Grace boasts a surprisingly epic feel for a film devoid of any gladiators or soldiers dying on the battlefield.Though its themes are powerfully presented, Amazing Grace would not have achieved its pronounced conviction were it not for the overwhelming talent of its cast. Ioan Gruffudd magnificently portrays the brazen speaker with rebellious charm and heartfelt sincerity from his stunning accomplishments to his tragic defeats. Aiding him in his ceaseless crusade are Pitt (Benedict Cumberbatch) and Clarkson (Rufus Sewell) who both give strong performances; Pitt as a figurehead working behind the scenes and Clarkson as his resolute right-hand man. Michael Gambon effortlessly scene steals as the cynically droll Lord Fox, ever ready with his sharp tongue and comedically commanding presence. Albert Finney also turns in a bold portrayal of John Newton, the former slave ship captain who wrote the title song and sought forgiveness for his sins. The antagonistic Lord Tarleton (Ciaran Hinds) and Duke of Clarence (Toby Jones) add a refined touch of villainy to their characters, creating a far more satisfying conclusion when they finally fall to the band of ingenious heroes. Not a dull performance exists in this graceful drama, and even the rather expected love interest is handled refreshingly by the lovely Romola Garai.Perhaps a bit over sentimental at times, Amazing Grace still captivates with its diverse cast of exceptional talent, often movingly witty dialogue, magnificent recreations of 18th century costumes and sets, and the incredible true story of one man's unceasing quest for justice. Thankfully relinquishing any long-winded speeches, Amazing Grace allows the actions of the dauntless Wilberforce and his followers to do what they do best - speak for themselves.- Joel Massie

reviewText: Amazing Grace is the story of William Wilberforce, a Member of Parliament chiefly responsible for the abolition of slavery in the British Empire in the latter part of the 18th century and beginning of the 19th. Focusing on the political struggle as opposed to the individual stories of slaves themselves, the film's creators have crafted a moving and highly entertaining story of a now mostly forgotten period in world history.We begin with an introduction to the 'ordinary world' of Wilberforce. Right away he's depicted as someone who is compassionate toward animals after he alights from his coach and prevents two men from beating a horse (it's one of Blake Snyder's 'Save the Cat' moments: according to screen writing guru Snyder, a good screenplay always has a moment early on where the protagonist does a good deed, creating audience sympathy). After Wilberforce arrives at his cousin's estate, he dreams of smashing glasses during a banquet held by high society people, foreshadowing his struggle with pro-slavery forces throughout the movie. We're also introduced to Barbara Spooner, the woman he eventually marries. No sparks fly between them during their first meeting and Wilberforce appears disinterested with the prospect of hooking up with her. Wilberforce is depicted as a complex character from the outset. But his moral compass is always firm (as he looks in the mirror, images of slaves in chains appear--these flashbacks to the actual scenes of slavery are never overdone).Before we break into Act 2 of the story, there's always some kind of 'inciting incident' or catalyst which gets the action moving. In Amazing Grace, the flashback to 15 years earlier, marking Wilberforce's early career as a politician, is the actual inciting incident. We see the extremely articulate and witty Wilberforce as a young man in Parliament, debating with conservatives over the course of the war with America. There's a great scene where the Duke of Clarence (brilliantly played by Toby Jones) shocks our modern day sensibilities with his request to "fetch my n-gger"--his black servant is brought in and offered by the Duke as a wager during a card game with Wilberforce. While Wilberforce does walk out in disgust, he doesn't hold a grudge against his fellow MP's (Members of Parliament). He realizes he needs to work with these people and movingly sings 'Amazing Grace' to show them just where his sentiments lie. Wilberforce's internal conflict is dramatized as he communes with nature on his country estate. He's conflicted about whether he should pursue a solitary spiritual life as opposed to continuing his career in politics. His servant who quotes Francis Bacon, points out that serving God and pursuing political ends in the cause of justice are not incompatible. Wilberforce's eccentric personality is also depicted: his mansion is overflowing with animals and beggars who he can't say no to--bent on obtaining a free lunch.We break into Act 2 when the a group of abolitionists visit Wilberforce. The key moment is when Henry Clarkson, one of the more radical abolitionists, displays the actual chains at the dinner table used by slave traders and when former slave Olaudah Equiano opens his shirt to reveal how he was branded during the time of his captivity. The first half of Act 2 of Amazing Grace involves the initial successes of the abolitionists. We skip forward to the 'present time' and a series of events unfold including Wilberforce's developing relationship with Barbara Spooner, introduction of the principal antagonist, Lord Tarleton, the defection of Charles Fox, the pro-slavery MP who joins the small group of anti-slavery MPs, and Wilberforce dramatically forcing upper crust Londoners (partying on a boat) to take in the "smell of death' from a slave ship docked in the Harbor. The midpoint of the story is usually a 'false victory' for the protagonist and his allies. In Amazing Grace, the abolitionists' publicity campaign is working. Fifty thousand copies of Equiano's book have been sold in two months and Wilberforce remarks (in a voice-over), "our message was everywhere."The second half of Act 2 usually leads to a temporary defeat for the protagonist. Despite collecting 390,000 signatures on a petition and presenting it to Parliament, the war with France has turned public opinion against the abolitionists. Slavery is seen as necessary to the economy and the public now believes its abolition will undermine the war effort. Prime Minister Pitt can no longer support Wilberforce given the changed political realities. The end of Act 2 usually features a 'dark moment of the soul' for the protagonist. Members of the public walk out on an anti-slavery deacon's sermon and Wilberforce has another attack of his 'colitis', symbolizing the effect of the pro-slavery forces' counterattack.At the beginning of Act 3, the protagonist must regroup and once again attempt to battle his opponents. Wilberforce's wedding to Barbara Spooner serves as a brief respite before he goes into battle once again. This time, the abolitionists are aided by James Stevens, a lawyer who devises a plan to seize French ships sailing under neutral American flags. Since 80% of slave ships are under the American flag, removing the protection of the neutral flags, will effectively end the slave trade. The climax occurs when Wilberforce and his allies give free racetrack tickets to MPs who aren't there for the crucial vote regarding the French ships.Wilberforce now returns to his 'ordinary world' which has been transformed. His life has been renewed--he's now able to cope with his crippling colitis and his wife has given him six children. Finally, he lives to see an 283 to 16 vote in Parliament abolishing slavery throughout the British empire. Amazing Grace is not only a great history lesson. The casting and performances are superb and the story is inspirational. This is a film that should be viewed multiple times.
summary: Exceptional history lesson and inspirational drama

reviewText: I must admit that I didn't know who William Wilberforce was before I saw this film, nor did I know that the composer John Newton had once been a slave trader.  It's the kind of historical knowledge that more people should become familiar with.I was impressed with WW's commitment to social justice, more compassion for animals, and improvements in health care and education.  Ioan Gruffudd does a nice job in the role of WW, as does Albert Finney, who plays his mentor, John Newton.  Ciaran Hinds and Toby Jones are at the top of their game as the main opposition in the House of Commons.It would have been more effective to have more slaves featured so we could hear their point of view; as it is, only one former slave gets to say anything about his horrific experiences.Overall, however, this is a story worth getting to know.

reviewText: I ordered Amazing Grace after seeing part of it on television. I was impressed with the quality of the movie. I also am a big fan of the tune Amazing Grace played on the bagpipes, and the version at the end of this movie was impressive--it brought tears to my eyes.Some have described this as the true story behind the song, but that is not accurate. It is a depiction of the fight in British Parliament to pass a law banning slavery in that country and its territories. I am intrigued by true stories from history, and was not disappointed in this one.I recommend this movie because of the historical significance of the subject, but also because of the well-acted rendering of the movie.
